awd_titl_txt: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Early Development of Territorial Strategies
awd_abstract_narration:
This project investigates the relationships among politics, economics, and space in the development of territories in early complex societies. The territory, understood as the political organization of space, is fundamental for the characterization of both pre-modern societies and contemporary ones. Nowadays, there are still debates between protectionist views that argue that polities and regions can thrive by their own in isolation, and more globalists ones that focus on issues of cooperation and competition at a larger, even global, scale. This debate also raises questions on the territorial notion based on the nation-state and the spatial correspondence, or lack of it, between political and economic systems. By addressing these relationships at an early stage in the development of complex societies, the project will contribute to the current debate by assessing the relative weight of both economic and political interactions in the rise of social and regional inequalities. The project will address issues of territoriality, not only related to specific resources, but embedded in a broader social network where connections and links may be as important as the resources themselves.

The project will test two alternative hypotheses regarding territorial strategies by assessing if the locations of secondary sites are related to the control of accesses or communication routes: 1) early polities locate themselves where they can take advantage of the broad trade networks without an attempt to control a defined geographical space, or 2) early polities tried to increase their access to, and even control, trade networks by expanding their geographical dominance through the establishment of dependent secondary sites in potential alternative routes beyond its own location. To test the hypotheses, the project will use (1) settlement patterns and spatial modeling to identify if site location was associated with regional and interregional communication routes, (2) record architectural layout patterns among sites to construct a rank hierarchy and infer political dependency, and (3) analyze artifact distributions to infer resource fluxes, relationships among sites, and identify extra regional connections. With this data, the project will be able to characterize the spatial organization of an early polity, and gain insight on the mechanisms behind the development of early complex societies, their spatial relationships, and the political construction of space, to ultimately contribute to our understanding of the processes that have modeled the contemporary political landscape.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
The project focused on understanding the territorial dynamics at the border between two small independent polities: Coita and Mirador. To achieve this, an archaeological survey was done on 27 square kilometers recording 53 previously unknown archaeological sites. Among these sites twelve had one large mound, more than a dozen small structures, or considerable extension of surface ceramics. Based on the evidence recovered from these sites, the project identified different territorial strategies corresponding to different time periods.

The earliest evidence corresponds to the Escalera phase (ca. 750?500 BCE) at the site of ?Guachipilin? which contained  foreign ceramics associated to the Olmec site of La Venta, suggesting this site was a node in the long-distance communication routes.

By the Francesa Phase (ca. 500-250 BC) mound construction began in the survey area. The site of ?Juan Abad?a? was closely linked with Coita. This site?s location suggests an effort from this polity to increase the access to productive land. On the other side, the site of San Jorge is related to Mirador, and was focused on controlling  communications routes to the polity center rather than an interest in agricultural production.

During the following Guanacaste Phase (ca. 250-100 BC) we found an increase in the occupation of the area, both with large sites and several small ones. The largest site of this phase is ?Malacate? located at the middle point between Mirador and Coita. The Guanacaste components were based on two different ceramic types: Mirador and Sierra. In the sites, one or the other type is found, but very rarely do two of them coexist. The sites with Mirador ceramics form a line from ?San Jorge?, passing through ?Malacate?, towards ?Guachipil?n?, and avoiding the sites of ?Juan Abad?a? and Tamarindo, which seems more related to Coita.

The center of the site of ?Abidaul?, whose main occupation was during the Jiquipilas Phase, is surrounded by a peripheral wall. A feature not seen in any other sites in the survey. Due to its closeness to Coita, the similarities in their artifacts, and its architectural characteristics, this site may represent an effort from Coita to gain access to this stablished communication route.

During the following Lagunas Phase (ca. AD 450-650) most of the survey area seems to have been abandoned with the notable exception of the site of ?Iglesia Vieja? which seems to have gone through a moment of significant construction. Site  abandonment  during the Lagunas phase is not exclusive of our survey area. It was also identified in other regions of Chiapas such as the Frailesca area and may correspond to population movements to the large centers of the period such as Teotihuacan.

The Late Classic Period or Maravillas Phase (ca. AD 650-900) represents a reoccupation of the survey area that continued during the Postclassic Period. The three largest sites, in terms of number of archaeological structures correspond to this late occupation. These sites are ?Tamarindo?, ?Gavilan?, and ?Puente Tempisque?. Among the archaeological structures identified in the last two there were ballgame courts, one at each site.

The data recovered by the project, suggest different territorial strategies for different periods of time that should be related to both local and broad scale processes to gain insight of the importance od spatial variables in the development and expansion on the pollical complexity.
